<Marcin> With regards to zkvm standardization efforts:

@jbruestle, according to https://dev.risczero.com/api/zkvm/zkvm-specification (https://dev.risczero.com/api/zkvm/zkvm-specification) Risc0 implemented 0 "page" as non-accessible to catch null pointer accesses. Do you have any thoughts about null pointer handling in C#, Go or in other languages and the utility of 0 "page" accesses trapping?

@jordibaylina <@718410824711929886> @alex_vlasoff @jbruestle @jpwang , more input is welcome and *needed*: https://github.com/eth-act/zkvm-standards/pull/8#discussion_r2589009097 (https://github.com/eth-act/zkvm-standards/pull/8#discussion_r2589009097)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<jbruestle> re: **@Marcin**
> With regards to zkvm standardization efforts:

@jbruestle, according to https://dev.risczero.com/api/zkvm/zkvm-specification Risc0 implemented 0 "page" as non-accessible to catch null pointer accesses. Do you have any thoughts about null pointer handling in C#, Go or in other languages and the utility of 0 "page" accesses trapping?

@jordibaylina <@718410824711929886> @alex_vlasoff @jbruestle @jpwang , more input is welcome and needed: https://github.com/eth-act/zkvm-standards/pull/8#discussion_r2589009097
Re null pointers, yes, the current R0VM fails to prove (i.e. hard faults) on access to the zero page as a security feature, which would be problematic for say C# code that relies on catching null pointer dereferences and continuing execution in some way.  However, the version of the R0VM currently under development has an MMU that goes to a trap handler on illegal access instead, and so would be able to emulate the C# behavior.  Unclear how other VMs handle the zero page.
